scenes.title: Introduction
scenes.narration_text: In the courtyards of India stands a tree known as the 'Village Pharmacy'. This is the Neem tree. For centuries, it has been revered not just for its shade, but for its incredible healing powers.
scenes.visual_prompt: A large, majestic Neem tree in a traditional Indian village courtyard. Sunlight filters through its leaves.

scenes.title: Origins
scenes.narration_text: The Neem tree is native to the Indian subcontinent. Its scientific name is Azadirachta indica. In Sanskrit, it is called 'Arishta', which means 'the one that cures diseases'.
scenes.visual_prompt: A botanical illustration of a Neem branch with leaves and fruits, overlaid on an old map of India.

scenes.title: Medicinal Uses
scenes.narration_text: Every part of the Neem tree is useful. Its leaves are a natural antiseptic, used to treat skin conditions and keep germs away. Neem twigs were traditionally used as toothbrushes to keep teeth healthy.
scenes.visual_prompt: Close up of fresh green neem leaves and a traditional neem twig toothbrush.

scenes.title: Agricultural Uses
scenes.narration_text: Neem is also a farmer's best friend. Neem seed powder is a natural pesticide. It repels harmful insects like locusts and termites without harming the environment or the crops.
scenes.visual_prompt: A farmer standing in a healthy green field, holding a handful of neem seeds.

scenes.title: Modern Applications
scenes.narration_text: Today, neem is used in soaps, shampoos, and medicines all over the world. It purifies the air and cools the environment. Truly, the Neem tree is nature's gift to mankind.
scenes.visual_prompt: Modern products like neem soap and oil bottles arranged neatly, with a neem tree in the background.
